comments.commentBody:
The Republicans are completely and totally responsible for whatever happens from here. Good or bad. They own it all.

Let's hope for the best, but it already doesn't look good.

That Mr. Trump would try to use the presidency for personal enrichment will come as no surprise to anyone one who followed the campaign or studied his history.

Democrats and the media must never stop calling this for what it is: bribery. The media and Democrats should never hesitate to mention that Mr. Trump is in violation of Article II, Section 4 of the Constitution - which names bribery as an impeachable offense - every time he engages in any activity which could be seen as bribery. A recent example is the renting of rooms in his new Pennsylvania Ave. hotel by foreign diplomats. (There would be no conflict of interest if Mr. Trump put his assets in a true blind trust.)

And Democrats should not hesitate to call for Mr. Trump's impeachment if necessary. The media should not normalize his behavior, either. It is an impeachable offense, and must be treated as such.

Mr. Luettgen: Are you sure all those assets in Trump's name are really his assets? Or are a great many of them owned by concealed investors all over the world? Since Trump arrogantly refuses to allow the public access to his tax returns - which in my view should disqualify him from the presidency - we don't know what his assets really are or whom they actually belong to. He may be simply on loan, as it were, from interests who  control him  - and who could exercise an unhealthy measure of control over the affairs of this country. He may be the Manchurian candidate in plain sight. Or am I just being cynical?

Republicans don't care if Trump has conflicts of interest that will embroil him in controversy. Once that threshold is breached and he starts to stink, they'll drop him just as quickly as they embraced him once they realized he was going to win. They'll make themselves look like heroes once they push him out the door. They made their deal with the devil long ago, sidling up to him just close enough to grab his coattails but not close enough to get too slimy. He's their Trojan Horse. Once he's no longer useful, they'll toss him aside. They're using him, and he using them. They have nothing to lose by getting behind him now, and putting him behind them later.

Expecting the Republicans in Congress to hold Trump accountable for his enormous conflicts of interest is laughable.

During the campaign, Ryan, McConnell, McCain, Chaffetz, Rubio and so many others endorsed Trump despite his racism, misogyny, tax evasion, criticisms of military heroes, vulgarity and other antics that made a mockery of the GOP's desired image of being pro military and pro family values. Whether out of concerns about their own careers or a desire to retake the White House and Supreme Court no matter what, they stuck with him even after the release of the video bragging about sexually assaulting women. Why on Earth should we expect them to stand up to him now?

But just try telling this to the people who elected him (not to mention the Republican Congress). If this type of issue mattered to these people, they wouldn't have voted for him. This is a whole new world; a world where things like the emoluments clause and the appearance of wrongdoing have no role, but the appearance of success does. This is why tourists are lining up outside Trump Tower to get in to the Trump souvenir store to buy "Success" aftershave.

It's in everyone's best interest to have an open and transparent government. I think (hope) most Americans would agree to that. It's clear that Trump will never do the right thing (it's not in his character), and it's very unlikely that Republican members of congress will challenge him unless they hear from their constituents. They need frequent reminders that they are accountable to us, not the other way around. So it is up to all of us  (Republicans and Democrats) to call, write, and email our representatives to let them know that we expect them to pressure Trump into releasing his tax records and to establish a process, as the Times suggests, to review his business ventures. The election is now over, but the fight to save the country that we all love is now on - "bigly."

The rest of the world is watching us keenly to see how this plays out. Perhaps America will finally lose the moral authority to preach against corruption to third world countries and banana republics. A President who not only refuses to meet conventional ethical standards but also encourages his heirs to sniff around foreign leaders in an effort to maximize every opportunity to expand their empire. We can forget about linking our generous foreign aid to governmental transparency and accountability on the part of the recipient countries.

Between taking care of his businesses around the world and developing others, making sure his children, close family and cronies are lucratively employed, meeting with present and prospective business partners, dealing with pending lawsuits from assorted investors and stiffed contractors, and of course sending enraged tweets to critics like SNL and even the most insignificant targets, I wonder President Trump will have any time or remaining brain cells to devote to the country and the voters who elected him.

Donald Trump "Hail to the Chief" and "Takin' Care of Business."

Trump is not a king, he's a servant of the people. The fact the president-elect says he intends to conduct business in the White House should be a smack-in-the-mouth wake up call to all Americans, especially those who voted for him.  Trump promised to work tirelessly for the blue collar working class, the working poor and millions of others who don't have a voice in government. And to think Trump believes the presidency is a part-time job. I wonder what the living presidents think about that. The idea of America being second choice in a decision made in the White House is unthinkable.

So far, Trump's supporters seem to be completely unconcerned by these real and potential conflicts of interest.  Until that changes, and they begin to question his actions, questions coming from the Democrats, the press and anyone else concerned with the ethics of the situation will not change anything.

I'm skeptical that Mr. Trump or his party or his sycophants much care. They have been infected by the sickness of greed and power. They foresee the largest combined transfers of money in world history--Medicare and Social Security; big energy running rampant to extract and exploit with little regulatory restraint of the quid pro quo; possibly handing the power to set the terms or deny terms for those in need of affordable health insurance right back to the companies from whom the power had been partially removed by the ACA; privatizing the would-be profit centers of roads, schools, water and other local, state and federal government functions; ending the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and most other big finance regulations that somewhat dissuade brazen manipulation of the markets, and so on. The list is long. The point is: there may be too little prudence or mindfulness in this vulture capitalism. The greater point is: if the so-called leader takes with little restraint, his family and lackeys will be emboldened to deny or reject ethics, the nation is stuck with an astronomical tab, and everyone learns too late that the pathology has had ruinous consequences.

The Republican party has been complicit with Trump, including those Republicans who disavowed him and then endorsed him.  Why would anyone think that they will become models of ethical behavior and call him on his conflicts of interest?  Trump is highly pugilistic and gets even, unless the Republican establishment impeaches him and votes him out of office in favor of Mike Pence.  Trump or Pence?  It doesn't really matter.  One is just as bad as the other.  Either way we're in trouble.  God help us all.

The problem here is that Donald Trump has admitted that he doesn't use email, and the Republicans in Congress have shown over the fast four years that emails are the only thing they know how to investigate (and not even very well at that). So, Ryan and McConnell will be content to sit back and work with Trump's designated worker bee, Mike Pence, while Trump pretends he is King and reaps whatever rewards he can over the next four years, or heaven help us more.

He will believe he is beloved by his people because many of the same old folks will show up at his rallies, oblivious to the fact that they have been scammed, and Trump's people will not tell him how he is making a mockery of the Presidency. Ultimately he will go down in history as one of the most venal, corrupt politicians in US history. And his kids will take that to the bank.

Conflict of interest is the polite term for what Donald Trump is doing.  The more accurate term is corruption, or more specifically the use of public office for private gain.  Let's call this for what it is.  The core of our system of government is integrity and transparency.  We need to insist that everyone, President and Vice President included, abide by these core principles.

If you want to see how a Tump presidency could unfold, I suggest you look at the history of Silvio Bersconi in Italy. In terms of their backgrounds, the ascendance to leadership in their respective counries and their eventual "modus operundai" while in office, the parallels between the two is eerily similar. They could be "evil twins". We now know what happened in Italy and it did not end very well for either Berlusconi OR for Italy.

For the sake of America and despite evidence to the contrary, one can only hope a Trump presidency doesn't end up the same way.

Please keep posting these types of editorials, and do the investigative reporting needed to expose his corruption.  I am disheartened that he doesn't seem to care.  The congress doesn't care.  His legions of voters don't care.  We're not just post-truth, we are post-ethics, post-morality, and post-patriotism.  I feel like the mother of a teenager again, getting the eyeroll and the sneer when asking for more civilized behavior.   I pray that the nation can withstand and recover from this.

How is it that I can lose my job for accepting anything of value greater than $5 from a foreign company I'm doing business with and our President, who works for the same government can get away with this?.  In some cases, according to our training, egregious violations of ethics, bribery, and undue foreign influence can lead to jail time. We have training upon training in ethics, foreign influence, and we are hammered on not doing ANYTHING that can even APPEAR to be unethical.  Obviously, the Don never had any such training.

Politicians of both parties, including Bill and Hillary Clinton, routinely become fabulously wealthy during or immediately after "public service", and the privatized American campaign financing system is rotten to core with bought laws, judges and special tax breaks. And we're worried about hotels and golf courses?

Who in politics today has the moral authority to police Trump? And who among them will risk exposure, in return for going after him?
What hypocrisy! Perhaps we should refer to Trump in the future  as  President Trump Inc.

The Times notes that Donald Trump's conflicts of interest are an invitation for corruption by foreign governments and businesses, presumably by favoring his businesses, in order to influence American policies. The risk is obvious given how he links his wealth -and now his election win- to his grandiosity. However, I think that this editorial misses another reason why foreign nations might want to pay Donald Trump a favor: as a cost-effective insurance against his bad character.

As a business man, Donald Trump has all the appearance of an untrustworthy, profit-seeking bully who splits the world in pure black and white and who seems seems oblivious to the subtle and the complex. So much for conventional diplomacy. Foreign nations may simply want to buy a form of insurance against the unpredictability of a bully who has access to the power of the mightiest nation on Earth. This would seem a very reasonable step to do. His conflicts of interest and his character definitely ask - no, beg - for corruption and flattery.

Who wouldn't prefer to conclude a discussion with president Trump like the New York Times last week? "The is a great, great jewel. A world jewel. And I hope we can all get along." This sounds much better than the alternative 3 a.m. tweets.

The opposite of bribery might be even more effective in influencing Trump: "Mr. President, if you don't do X, we will increase the taxes on your hotels; we will build a dump next to your golf course; we will restrict travel to our country of your children and agents; we wil advertize against your brand; we will forbid our citizens' working for you."

The bottom line is that Hillary Clinton supporters didn't blink at her obvious conflicts, and trading on her position of Secretary of State for personal gain, My personal feeling is that Trump is entitled to the benefit of the doubt at this point in time. However, if the potential conflicts suggested in the editorial come to pass, Trump supporters will also probably overlook them, and continue to support him wholeheartedly. BTW, this observer didn't vote for either Hillary or Donald.

It is near impossible to overstate the set of double standards that were applied to both candidates during the campaign. In an 'Alice -Through-the-Looking Glass' world one candidate was deemed 'guilty' on no evidence and the other was deemed 'innocent' despite ample evidence.

Should Trump's base and the GOP continue with this unwillingness to scrutinize this man he will 'shill' his corporate brand right throughout his tenure.

Quite a few commenters here come to the conclusion that the president-elect might be impeached within a year after taking office, because of his crooked businesses conflicts stretching around the globe and playing footsie with dictators.. That is my opinion as well.

But then what? Instead of a gaudy and vulgar Crook-in-Chief we'll receive a deluded, oh-so-pious Pastor-in-Chief, one popier than the pope?

More than half the nation is still in shock about the result of this past election. When reading foreign publications - even the ones from the center right - it is clear that the governments of all advanced nations are in collective shock about the man they have to deal with in the future.

It is highly doubtful that even center right politicians, Chancellor Angela Merkel, PM Theresa May et.al will be amused when Ivanka and Jared are listening in on daddy-dearest's phone calls, or even attending a face-to-face meetings as well.

This country has once more become the butt of the joke abroad, except that this latest joke frightens the bejesus out of our allies.
